article_title: 2nd Circ. Case Will Have Far-Reaching ERISA Implications
article_text:
2nd Circ. Case Will Have Far-Reaching ERISA Implications

Law360, New York (June 23, 2014, 11:15 AM ET) -- When a general liability policy expressly provides coverage for employee benefits liability and the plaintiff in the underlying suit alleges a violation of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, does the insurer have a duty to defend the suit? Resoundingly, yes, according to the Second Circuit in a well-reasoned opinion handed down on June 10.

article_metadata.description: The Second Circuit's decision in Euchner-USA Inc. v. Hartford Casualty Ins. Co. is doubly significant. First, for its rejection of commonly asserted insurer defenses to coverage for Employee Retirement Income Security Act claims. Further, future private litigation — including class actions — under the Affordable Care Act may well implicate employee benefits liability coverage issues that have been decided in the ERISA context, says James Scheuermann of K&L Gates LLP.
